descriptions.title: An Overview of the Golok Nomadic Area
descriptions.content: Golok (mgo log) is a distinct ethno-cultural region by virtue of its dialects, origin narratives, tribal and clan groupings, explicit identity statements, and life-style and ecology. The dialects spoken in the Golok region are a variation of nomadic Amdo dialects ('brog skad), distinct from the farming areas to the north and east, but grading into the Ngaba (rnga ba) dialect to the southeast, and running up against the Kham dialects (khams skad) Yushu to the south west. In contemporary China, there is a Golok TAP based on this perceived unity. The areas around Golok are more difficult in terms of classification. Pastoralist communities extend from Golok southeast through Ngaba (rnga ba), Mewa (rme ba) and Dzogay (mdzo dge), which have traditionally been referred to as Shimdrok (spelling?). They are quite similar to Golok, and thus their most natural classification is not immediately apparent. (Toni Huber – June 01, 2004)
